å…­å€‹è»Œé“åƒæ•¸çš„ç‰©ç†æ„ç¾©

  • semi-major axiså’Œeccentricityé€™å…©å€‹åƒæ•¸ä¸»è¦æ˜¯ç”¨ä¾†æè¿°è»Œé“å½¢ç‹€å¤§å°;
  • è€Œinclinationå’Œlongitude of the ascending node é€™å…©å€‹åƒæ•¸åœ¨æè¿°è»Œé“å¹³é¢ç›¸è¼ƒæ–¼é»ƒé“é¢(as reference frame)çš„æ“ºæ”¾è§’åº¦å’Œä½ç½®;

çœ‹çœ‹èƒ½ä¸èƒ½æ‰“å‡ºæ­£å¸¸çš„æ•¸å­¸å…¬å¼.....

èˆ‰å€‹ä¾‹å­ æ —å­ğŸŒ° \[ \begin{equation}\label{eq.1} e=mc^2 \end{equation} \] è‘—åçš„è´¨èƒ½æ–¹ç¨‹ \(\eqref{eq.1}\) ç”±çˆ±å› æ–¯å¦æå‡º ...

å¯¹äºå¤šè¡Œå…¬å¼ï¼Œåœ¨ equation ç¯å¢ƒä¸­ï¼Œä½ å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ aligned ç¯å¢ƒæŠŠå…¬å¼åˆ†æˆå¤šè¡Œï¼Œ

\[ \begin{equation}\label{eq.2} \begin{aligned} a &= b + c \\ &= d + e + f + g \\ &= h + i \end{aligned} \end{equation} \] Consider a comet is not close with initial semi-major \(a\), eccentricity \(e\), inclination \(i\). After encountering Jupiter, the orbital element of the comet becomes semi-major \(a'\), eccentricity \(e'\), inclination \(i'\)

From the Jacobi integral \(C_J\), it remains constant value throughout the encounter with the masses \(^{[3]}\).

\[ \begin{equation}\label{eq02} \begin{aligned} C_J &= 2V - v^2 \\&= 2(\frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2}) + 2n(\dot x' y' - x' \dot y') - ( \dot x'^2 + \dot y'^2 + \dot z'^2 ) \label{cj} \end{aligned} \end{equation} \] For instance in Sun-Jupiter-comet problem, because the mass of Jupiter is smaller than Sun \((M_j \sim 10^{-3}M_\odot)\), we take \(\mu_1\) and \(r_1\) as the unity. refer oto eq. \(\ref{eq02}\)

$ \[ \begin{equation} \begin{aligned} GM_\odot = \mu_1 = \mu \end{aligned} \end{equation} \]

\[ r_1 = r \]

entry.title: Lagrangian Equilibrium Pointslargrange_points
entry.content:
Lagrangian Equilibrium Points

Looking for the equilibrium points in the rotating coordinate frame, so that its position with respect to the two masses keep from a constant distance.

The equation of the motion in the rotating frame are these equations by moving the centrifugal term (\(n^2x\) and \(n^2y\) ) to the right-hand side of equation.

\(x\)-direction:

\[ (\ddot xÂ  -2n\dot y ) = \frac{\partial{V}}{\partial{x}}= - [ \mu_1 \frac{(\mu_2+x)}{r_1^{3}} + \mu_2 \frac{(x-\mu_1)}{r_2^{3}} ] + n^2x \]

\(y\)-direction:

\[ Â (\ddot y + 2n \dot x )= \frac{\partial{V}}{\partial{y}}= (\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} )\cdot y + n^2y \]

\(z\)-direction:

\[ \ddot z = \frac{\partial{V}}{\partial{z}}= - (\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} +Â  \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} )\cdotÂ  \]

\[ V(r) = V(x, y, z) \\ = \frac{n^2}{2}(x^2+y^2) + \frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2} \]

\[ r_1^2 = (x_1-x)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \\ = (\mu_2+x)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \]

\[ r_2^2 = (x_1-x)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \\ = (x-\mu_1)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \]

where \(\mu_1=Gm_1=\frac{m_1}{m_1+m_2}\) \(\mu_2=\bar{\mu}=Gm_1=\frac{m_2}{m_1+m_2}\)

\(\mu_1 + \mu_2 = 1\)

Here, mean motion n is taken as unity \((n=1)\)

The velocity of equilibrium points would be

\[ \dot x = \dot y =\dot z = \ddot x = \ddot y =\ddot z = 0 \]

From Equation , we must have \(z=0\) for the equilibrium points, thus, the equilibrium points are in the orbital plane of two masses. Therefore, based on Equation , Equation and Equation becomes

\[ Â \frac{\partial{V}}{\partial{x}} = 0 = -[ \mu_1 \frac{(\mu_2+x)}{r_1^{3}} + \mu_2 \frac{(x-\mu_1)}{r_2^{3}} ] + x \]

\[ Â \frac{\partial{V}}{\partial{y}} = 0 = (\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} )\cdot y + yÂ  \]

Where \(r_1= (\mu_2+1)^2 + y^2, r_2= (x-\mu_1)^2 + y^2\) Equation for y-direction is rewritten as

\[ y \cdot [ 1- (\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ) ] = 0 \]

So we have two kinds of the solution:

  • when \(y \neq 0\) is for the triangular points (\(L_4\) and \(L_5\))
  • when \(y = 0\) is for the collinear points (\(L_1, L_2\), and \(L_3\))

Triangular points (when \(y \neq 0\) )

From Equation

\[ Â y \cdot [ 1- (\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ) ] = 0 ~~~~(\because y \neq 0 ) \]

\[ \implies [ 1- (\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ) ] = 0Â  \]

Equation is multiplied by \((x+\mu_2)\)

\[ (x+\mu_2)- (x+\mu_2)(\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ) = 0 \\Â  (x+\mu_2)- (x+\mu_2)\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} - (x+\mu_2)\frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}}Â  = 0 \]

From x-direction Equation

\[ x -[ (\mu_2+x) \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + (x-\mu_1) \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ] = 0 \\ (\because \mu_1+\mu_2=1, ~~\mu_1 = 1- \mu_2) \\Â Â  Â  Â  Â  x - (\mu_2+x) \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} - (x-1+\mu_2) \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}}Â  = 0Â  \\Â  x-(\mu_2+x) \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} - (x+\mu_2) \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} = 0Â  \]

By subtracting Equation from Equation

\[ \mu_2- \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} = 0 \\ \implies r_2 = 1 \]

Equation is multiplied by \((x-\mu_1)\)

\[ Â (x-\mu_1)- (x-\mu_1)(\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ) = 0 \\Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â (x-\mu_1)- (x-\mu_1)\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} - (x-\mu_1)\frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}}Â  = 0 \]

From x-direction Equation

\[ x -[ (\mu_2+x) \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + (x-\mu_1) \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ] = 0 \\ (\because \mu_2 = 1- \mu_1) \\Â Â  Â  Â  Â  x - (1- \mu_1+x) \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} - (x- \mu_1) \frac{ \mu_2}{r_2^{3}}Â  = 0Â  \\Â Â  Â  Â  Â  x-(x-\mu_1) \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}}-\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} - (x-\mu_1) \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} = 0 \]

By subtracting Equation from Equation

\[ Â -\mu_1+ \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} = 0 \\ \implies r_1 = 1 \]

So \(r_1=r_2 = 1\), it is the distance between the two masses. Then, let's find the coordinate of \(L_4\) and \(L_5\)

From Equation

\[ Â r_1^2 = (\mu_2+x)^2 + y^2 = 1 \\Â Â  Â  Â  Â \mu_2^2 + 2\mu_2 x + x^2 +y^2 = 1 \]

From Equation

\[ r_2^2 = (x-\mu_1)^2 + y^2 = 1 \\Â Â  Â  Â  Â x^2 - 2x\mu_1 + \mu_1^2 +y^2 = 1 \\Â Â  Â  Â  Â (\because \mu_1 = 1- \mu_2) \\Â  Â  Â  Â x^2 - 2x(1-\mu_2) + (1-\mu_2)^2 +y^2 = 1 \\Â Â  Â  Â  Â x^2 -2x + 2\mu_2x +1 - 2\mu_2 + \mu_2^2 + y^2 = 1 \]

By subtracting Equation from Equation

\[ 1-2\mu_2-2x =0 \\ \implies 2(\mu_2+x) = 1 \\ \implies x=\frac{1}{2}-\mu_2 \]

Substituting \(x = \frac{1}{2}-\mu_2\) into Equation

\[ (\mu_2+x)^2 + y^2 = 1 \\ \implies [\mu_2+ (\frac{1}{2}-\mu_2) ]^2+y^2 = 1 \\ \implies y^2 = 1- \frac{1}{4} = \frac{3}{4} \\ \implies y = \frac{\pm \sqrt{3}}{2}Â  \]

Finally, we got the position of \(L_4\) and \(L_5\)

\(L_4\) Leading point: \(x=\frac{1}{2}-\mu_2\), \(y=\frac{+\sqrt{3}}{2}\)
\(L_5\) Trailing point: \(x=\frac{1}{2}-\mu_2\), \(y=\frac{- \sqrt{3}}{2}\)

Location of Lagrangian point \(L_4\) and \(L_5\)

Collinear points (when \(y = 0\) )

Equilibrium points lie along x-axis when \(y = 0\) , and satisfy \(\frac{\partial V}{\partial x} = 0\).

There are three solutions correspond to the "collinear Lagrangian equilibrium points" shown as Figure .

  • \(L_1\) point: between the mass \(\mu_1\) and \(\mu_2\)
  • \(L_2\) point: outside the mass \(\mu_2\) on the positive \(x\)-axis
  • \(L_3\) point: outside the mass \(\mu_1\) on the negative \(x\)-axis

Location of Lagrangian point \(L_1\), \(L_2\), and \(L_3\)

For the convenience of later calculation, we rewrite \(V(r)\), \(\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}\), and \(\frac{\partial V}{\partial y}\) as following: From Equation and Equation ,

\[ Â r_1^2 = (\mu_2+x)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \]

\[ Â r_2^2 =(x-\mu_1)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \]

Equation is multiplied by \(\mu_1\), and \(z=0\)

\[ \mu_1r_1^2 = \mu_1(\mu_2+x)^2 + \mu_1y^2 \]

Equation is multiplied by \(\mu_2\), and \(z=0\)

\[ \mu_2r_2^2 = \mu_2(x-\mu_1)^2 + \mu_2y^2 \]

By adding Equation to Equation

\[ \mu_1r_1^2 + \mu_2r_2^2 = y^2(\mu_1+\mu_2) + \mu_1(x^2 +2\mu_2x + \mu_2^2) + \mu_2(x^2 -2\mu_1x + \mu_1^2) \\ ~~~~~(\because \mu_1 + \mu_2 = 1) \\ = x^2 + y^2 + \mu_1^2\mu_2 + \mu_1\mu_2^2 \\ = x^2 + y^2 + \mu_1\mu_2(\mu_1+\mu_2) \\ \implies \mu_1r_1^2 + \mu_2r_2^2 = x^2 + y^2 + \mu_1\mu_2 \]

Based on Equation , Equation becomes

\[ V(r) = \frac{1}{2}(x^2+y^2) + \frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2} \\ = \frac{1}{2}(\mu_1r_1^2 + \mu_2r_2^2 - \mu_1\mu_2) + \frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2} \\ = \frac{-1}{2}\mu_1\mu_2 +\mu_1\frac{r_1^2}{2}+\mu_2\frac{r_2^2}{2} + \frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2} \\ = \mu_1(\frac{1}{r_1}+\frac{r_1^2}{2}) + \mu_2(\frac{1}{r_2}+\frac{r_2^2}{2})-\frac{1}{2}\mu_1\mu_2 \\ \implies V(r) = \mu_1(\frac{1}{r_1}+\frac{r_1^2}{2}) + \mu_2(\frac{1}{r_2}+\frac{r_2^2}{2})-\frac{1}{2}\mu_1\mu_2 \]

According to Equation , \(\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}\) is rewritten as

\[ \frac{\partial V}{\partial x} = \frac{\partial V}{\partial r_1}\frac{\partial r_1}{\partial x} + \frac{\partial V}{\partial r_2}\frac{\partial r_2}{\partial x} = 0 \\ = \mu_1 \cdot (\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \cdot[\frac{1}{2}((x+\mu_2)^2+y^2)^{1/2} \cdot 2(x+\mu_2)] \\ ~~~~ +\mu_2 \cdot (\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \cdot [\frac{1}{2}((x-\mu_1)^2+y^2)^{1/2} \cdot 2(x-\mu_1)] \\ = \mu_1\cdot (\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \frac{(x+\mu_2)}{r_1} +\mu_2 \cdot(\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \frac{(x-\mu_1)}{r_2} \\ \implies \frac{\partial V}{\partial x} = \mu_1(\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \cdot \frac{(x+\mu_2)}{r_1} +\mu_2(\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \cdot \frac{(x-\mu_1)}{r_2} \]

Also, \(\frac{\partial V}{\partial y}\) is rewritten as

\[ \frac{\partial V}{\partial y} = \frac{\partial V}{\partial r_1}\frac{\partial r_1}{\partial y} + \frac{\partial V}{\partial r_2}\frac{\partial r_2}{\partial y} = 0 \\ = \mu_1\cdot (\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \cdot[\frac{1}{2}((x+\mu_2)^2+y^2)^{1/2} \cdot 2y] \\ ~~~~ +\mu_2 \cdot (\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \cdot [\frac{1}{2}((x-\mu_1)^2+y^2)^{1/2} \cdot 2y] \\ = \mu_1 \cdot (\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \frac{y}{r_1} +\mu_2 \cdot (\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \frac{y}{r_2} \\ \implies \frac{\partial V}{\partial y} = \mu_1(\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \frac{y}{r_1} +\mu_2(\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \frac{y}{r_2} \]

Location of Lagrangian point \(L_1\)

For the \(L_1\) point, which is between the mass \(\mu_1\) and \(\mu_2\).

\[ r_1 + r_2 = 1, r_1 = x+\mu_2, r_2=-x+\mu_1 \]

Substituting the above condition into Equation

\[ \frac{\partial V}{\partial x} = \mu_1(\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \cdot \frac{(x+\mu_2)}{r_1} +\mu_2(\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \cdot \frac{(x-\mu_1)}{r_2} = 0 \\ = \mu_1(\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \cdot \frac{r_1}{r_1} +\mu_2(\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \cdot \frac{(-r_2)}{r_2} = 0 \\ ~~~~(\because r_1 = 1-r_2) \\ = \mu_1[\frac{-1}{(1-r_2)^2} + (1-r_2)] - \mu_2(\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) = 0 \\ \implies \mu_1[\frac{-1}{(1-r_2)^2} + (1-r_2)] = \mu_2(\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \]

\[ \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1} = \frac{\frac{-1}{(1-r_2)^2} + (1-r_2)}{\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2} ~~~~(\because \times (1-r_1)^2 \cdot r_1^2) \\ = \frac{ -r_2^2 + (1-r_2)^3 r_2^2 }{-(1-r_2)^2 + (1-r_2)^2r_2^3 } \\ = \frac{ r_2^2 [(1-r_2)^3-1]}{ (1-r_2)^2(r_2^3 -1)} \\ = \frac{ r_2^2 (1-3r_2+3r_2^2-r_2^3-1)}{ (1-2r_2+r_2^2)(r_2^3 -1)} \\ = \frac{ 3r_2^3 (1-r_2+\frac{1}{3}r_2^2)}{ (1-2r_2+r_2^2)(1-r_2^3)} \\ \]

Let \(\alpha = (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{1/3}\)

\[ \alpha = (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [\frac{(1-r_2+\frac{1}{3}r_2^2)}{ (1-2r_2+r_2^2)(1-r_2^3)} ]^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [\frac{(1-r_2+\frac{1}{3}r_2^2)}{ (1-2r_2+r_2^2-r_2^3+2r_2^4-r_2^5) } ]^{1/3} \]

Using Talyer's expression \(\frac{1}{1-x} = (1-x)^{-1} = 1+x+x^2+\mathcal{O}(x^3)...\) (if\(~ x \ll 1\))

The denominator of Equation becomes

\[ \frac{1}{1-x} = (1-x)^{-1} = 1+x+x^2+\mathcal{O}(x^3)\\ \implies \frac{1}{ (1-2r_2+r_2^2-r_2^3+2r_2^4-r_2^5) } \\ \approx 1+x+x^2 \\ ( \because x = 2r_2-r_2^2+r_2^3 , \\ ~~~~ x^2 = (2r_2-r_2^2+r_2^3)^2 \\ = 4r_2^2-2r_2^3-2r_2^4-2r_2^3+r_2^4-r_2+2r_2^3-r_2^5+r_2^6 \\ = 4r_2^2-2r_2^3-r_2^4-r_2^5+r_2^6 ~~~)\\ \approx 1+2r_2-r_2^2+r_2^3+ 4r_2^2-2r_2^3-r_2^4-r_2^5+r_2^6 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^7) \\ \approx 1 + 2r_2 + 3r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3) \]

\(\mathcal{O}(r_2^3)\) is the omitted terms because the value is small to neglect.

Substituting the result of Equation into Equation

\[ \alpha = (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [\frac{(1-r_2+\frac{1}{3}r_2^2)}{ (1-2r_2+r_2^2-r_2^3+2r_2^4-r_2^5) } ]^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [ (1-r_2+\frac{1}{3}r_2^2)(1 + 2r_2 + 3r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3)) ]^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [ 1+2r_2+3r_2^2 -r_2+2r_2^2- 3r_2^3 + \frac{1}{3}r_2^2 + \frac{2}{3}r_2^3 + r_2^4]^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [ 1+ r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2 - \frac{7}{3}r_2^3 + r_2^4 ]^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [ 1+ r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3)]^{1/3} \\ \]

Using binomial series \((1+x)^n = 1+nx + \frac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2 + \frac{n(n-1)(n-2)}{3!}x^3 + \mathcal{O}(x^4)\)

The part of Equation

\[ (1+x)^n = 1+nx + \frac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2 + \mathcal{O}(x^3) \\ \implies = [1+ r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3)]^{1/3} \\ \approx 1+nx + \frac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2 \\ ( \because n= \frac{1}{3} ,~~x = r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2 ,~~x^2 = (r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2)^2 ~~~)\\ = 1+ \frac{1}{3}( r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2) + \frac{1}{2}(\frac{1}{3})(\frac{1}{3}-1)(r_2^2+\frac{8}{3}r_2^3+\frac{16}{9}r_2^4) \\ = 1+ \frac{1}{3}r_2 + \frac{4}{9}r_2^2 + \frac{-1}{9}(r_2^2+\frac{8}{3}r_2^3+\frac{16}{9}r_2^4) \\ = 1+ \frac{1}{3}r_2 + \frac{1}{3}r_2^2 - \frac{8}{27}r_2^3 - \frac{16}{81}r_2^4 \\ = 1+ \frac{1}{3}r_2 + \frac{1}{3}r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3) \]

Therefore, Substituting the result of Equation into Equation

\[ \alpha = (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [ 1+ r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3)]^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [ 1+ \frac{1}{3}r_2 + \frac{1}{3}r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3)] \\ = r_2 +\frac{1}{3} r_2^2 + \frac{1}{3}r_2^3 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^4) \\ \]

Here, using Lagrangian's inversion method to invert the series expansions in Equation .

A variable \(z\) can be expressed as a function of a

\[ x = z + e \cdot \phi[x] ~~~~ (e<1) \]

Then \(x\) can also be expressed as a function of z using the relationship

\[ x = z + \sum_{j=1}^{+\infty} \frac{e^j}{j!} \frac{d^{j-1}}{dz^{j-1}}[\phi{(z)}]^j \]

Compared with Equation and Equation , we can write

\[ r_2 = \alpha - \frac{1}{3}[r_2^2+r_2^3 +\mathcal{O}(r_2^4) ] \\ = \alpha + (\frac{-1}{3})\phi(r_2) ~~~~(\because e=\frac{-1}{3}) \]

\[ \implies \phi(r_2) = r_2^2 +r_2^3 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^4) \]

and hence

\[ \phi(\alpha) = \alpha^2 + \alpha^3Â  \]

\[ [\phi(\alpha)]^2 = \alpha^4 + 2\alpha^5 + \alpha^6 \]

\[ \frac{d}{d\alpha}[\phi(\alpha)]^2Â  = 4\alpha^3 + 10\alpha^4 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^5)Â  \]

substituting the result of Equation , , and into Equation

\[ r_2 = \alpha + \sum_{j=1}^{+\infty} \frac{(\frac{-1}{3})^j}{j!} \frac{d^{j-1}}{dz^{j-1}}[\phi{z}]^j \\ = \alpha + \frac{\frac{-1}{3}}{1!}\phi(\alpha) + \frac{1}{2}(\frac{1}{9})\frac{d}{d\alpha}[\phi(\alpha)]^2 + ...\\ = \alpha + \frac{1}{3}(\alpha^2+\alpha^3) + \frac{1}{18}(4\alpha^3 + 10\alpha^4 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^5) ) \\ = \alpha - \frac{1}{3}\alpha^2 - \frac{1}{9}\alpha^3 + \frac{5}{9}\alpha^4 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^5) \\ \implies r_2 \approx \alpha(1-\frac{1}{3}\alpha-\frac{1}{9}\alpha^2 + \frac{5}{9}\alpha^3) \]

From previous condition,

\[ r_2 = -x + \mu_1 \\ \implies x = \mu_1 - r_2 \\ = \mu_1 - \alpha - \frac{1}{3}\alpha^2 - \frac{1}{9}\alpha^3 + \frac{5}{9}\alpha^4 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^5) \\ = \mu_1 - (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{1/3} - \frac{1}{3} (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{2/3} - \frac{1}{9} (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{3/3} + \frac{5}{9} (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{4/3} + \mathcal{O}( (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{5/3} \]

This is location of \(L_1\) point on \(x\)-axis.

Location of Lagrangian point \(L_2\)

For the \(L_2\) point, which is outside the mass \(\mu_2\).

\[ r_1 - r_2 = 1, r_1 = x+\mu_2, r_2=x-\mu_1 \]

Substituting the above condition into Equation

\[ \frac{\partial V}{\partial x} = \mu_1(\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \cdot \frac{(x+\mu_2)}{r_1} +\mu_2(\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \cdot \frac{(x-\mu_1)}{r_2} = 0 \\ = \mu_1(\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \cdot \frac{r_1}{r_1} +\mu_2(\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \cdot \frac{r_2}{r_2} = 0 \\ ~~~~(\because r_1 = r_2+1 ) \\ = \mu_1[\frac{-1}{(r_2+1)^2} + (r_2+1)] + \mu_2(\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) = 0 \\ \implies \mu_1[\frac{-1}{(r_2+1)^2} + (r_2+1)] = \mu_2(\frac{1}{r_2^2}-r_2) \]

\[ \implies \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1} = \frac{\frac{-1}{(r_2+1)^2} + (r_2+1)}{\frac{1}{r_2^2}-r_2} ~~~~(\because \times (1+r_2)^2 \cdot r_2^2) \\ = \frac{ -r_2^2 + (r_2+1)^3 r_2^2 }{(r_2+1)^2 - (r_2+1)^2r_2^3 } \\ = \frac{ r_2^2 [(r_2+1)^3-1]}{ (r_2+1)^2(1-r_2^3 )} \\ = \frac{ r_2^2 (1+3r_2+3r_2^2+r_2^3-1)}{ (1-2r_2+r_2^2)(1-r_2^3)} \\ = \frac{ 3r_2^3 (1+r_2+\frac{1}{3}r_2^2)}{ (1-2r_2+r_2^2)(1-r_2^3)} \\ = \frac{ 3r_2^3 (1+r_2+\frac{1}{3}r_2^2)}{ (1+2r_2 +r_2^2 -r_2^3 -2r_2^4 -r_2^5) } \]

Let \(\alpha = (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{1/3}\)

\[ \alpha = (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [ \frac{(1+r_2+\frac{1}{3}r_2^2)}{ (1-2r_2+r_2^2)(1-r_2^3)} ]^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [\frac{(1+r_2+\frac{1}{3}r_2^2)}{ (1+2r_2 +r_2^2 -r_2^3 -2r_2^4 -r_2^5)} ]^{1/3} \]

Using Talyer's expression \(\frac{1}{1-x} = (1-x)^{-1} = 1+x+x^2+\mathcal{O}(x^3).\).. (if \(x \ll 1\))

The denominator of Equation becomes

\[ \frac{1}{1-x} = (1-x)^{-1} = 1+x+x^2+\mathcal{O}(x^3)\\ \implies \frac{1}{(1+2r_2 +r_2^2 -r_2^3 -2r_2^4 -r_2^5) } \\ \approx 1+x+x^2 \\ ( \because x = -2r_2-r_2^2 , \\ ~~~~ x^2 = (-2r_2-r_2^2)^2 = 4r_2^2+42r_2^3+r_2^4 ~~) \\ = 1 + 2r_2-r_2^2 + 4r_2^2+42r_2^3+r_2^4 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^7) \\ = 1 - 2r_2 + 3r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3) \\ \]

\(\mathcal{O}(r_2^3)\) is the omitted terms because the value is small to neglect.

Substituting the result of Equation into Equation

\[ \alpha = (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [\frac{(1+r_2+\frac{1}{3}r_2^2)}{ (1 - 2r_2 + 3r_2^2 ) } ]^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [ (1-r_2+\frac{1}{3}r_2^2)(1 + 2r_2 + 3r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3)) ]^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [ 1- 2r_2+ 3r_2^2 + r_2+ 2r_2^2+ 3r_2^3 + \frac{1}{3}r_2^2 - \frac{2}{3}r_2^3 + r_2^4]^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [ 1- r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2 + \frac{7}{3}r_2^3 + r_2^4 ]^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [ 1- r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3)]^{1/3} \]

Using binomial series \((1+x)^n = 1+nx + \frac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2 + \frac{n(n-1)(n-2)}{3!}x^3 + \mathcal{O}(x^4)\)

The part of Equation

\[ (1+x)^n = 1+nx + \frac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2 + \mathcal{O}(x^3) \\ \implies = [1- r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3)]^{1/3} \\ \approx 1+nx + \frac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2 \\ ( \because n= \frac{1}{3} ,~~x = -r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2 ,~~ \\ x^2 = (-r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2)^2 = r_2^2 - \frac{8}{3}r_2^3+\frac{16}{9}r_2^4 ~~~)\\ = 1+ \frac{1}{3}(- r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2) + \frac{1}{2}(\frac{1}{3})(\frac{1}{3}-1)(r_2^2 -\frac{8}{3}r_2^3+\frac{16}{9}r_2^4) \\ = 1- \frac{1}{3}r_2 + \frac{4}{9}r_2^2 + \frac{-1}{9}(r_2^2- \frac{8}{3}r_2^3+\frac{16}{9}r_2^4) \\ = 1- \frac{1}{3}r_2 + \frac{1}{3}r_2^2 + \frac{8}{27}r_2^3 -\frac{16}{81}r_2^4 \\ = 1- \frac{1}{3}r_2 + \frac{1}{3}r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3) \]

Therefore, Substituting the result of Equation on Equation

\[ \alpha = (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [ 1- r_2 + \frac{4}{3}r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3)]^{1/3} \\ = r_2 [1- \frac{1}{3}r_2 + \frac{1}{3}r_2^2 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^3)] \\ = r_2 - \frac{1}{3} r_2^2 + \frac{1}{3}r_2^3 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^4) \\ \]

Here, using Lagrangian's inversion method as same as \(L_1\) to invert the series expansions in Equation .

\[ r_2 = \alpha + \frac{1}{3}[r_2^2-r_2^3 +\mathcal{O}(r_2^4) ] \\ = \alpha + (\frac{1}{3})\phi(r_2) ~~~~(\because e= \frac{1}{3}) \]

\[ \implies \phi(r_2) = r_2^2 - r_2^3 + \mathcal{O}(r_2^4) \]

And hence

\[ \phi(\alpha) = \alpha^2 - \alpha^3Â  \]

\[ [\phi(\alpha)]^2 = \alpha^4 - 2\alpha^5 + \alpha^6Â  \]

\[ \frac{d}{d\alpha}[\phi(\alpha)]^2Â  = 4\alpha^3 - 10\alpha^4 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^5) \]

Substituting the result of Equation , , and into Equation

\[ r_2 = \alpha + \sum_{j=1}^{+\infty} \frac{(\frac{1}{3})^j}{j!} \frac{d^{j-1}}{dz^{j-1}}[\phi{z}]^j \\ = \alpha + \frac{\frac{1}{3}}{1!}\phi(\alpha) + \frac{1}{2}(\frac{1}{9})\frac{d}{d\alpha}[\phi(\alpha)]^2 + ...\\ = \alpha + \frac{1}{3}(\alpha^2-\alpha^3) + \frac{1}{18}(4\alpha^3 - 10\alpha^4 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^5) ) \\ = \alpha + \frac{1}{3}\alpha^2 -\frac{1}{3}\alpha^3 +\frac{2}{9}\alpha^3 - \frac{5}{9}\alpha^4 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^5) \\ = \alpha + \frac{1}{3}\alpha^2 -\frac{1}{9}\alpha^3 - \frac{5}{9}\alpha^4 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^5) \\ \implies r_2 \approx \alpha(1+\frac{1}{3}\alpha-\frac{1}{9}\alpha^2 -\frac{5}{9}\alpha^3) \]

From previous condition,

\[ r_2 = x - \mu_1 \\ \implies x = \mu_1 + r_2 \\ = \mu_1 + \alpha + \frac{1}{3}\alpha^2 - \frac{1}{9}\alpha^3 - \frac{5}{9}\alpha^4 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^5) \\ = \mu_1 + (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{1/3} + \frac{1}{3} (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{2/3} - \frac{1}{9} (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{3/3} - \frac{5}{9} (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{4/3} + \mathcal{O}( (\frac{\mu_2}{3\mu_1})^{5/3} \]

This is location of \(L_2\) point on x-axis.

Location of Lagrangian point \(L_3\)

For the \(L_3\) point, which is outside the mass \(\mu_1\) on the negative x-axis.

\[ r_2 - r_1 = 1, r_1 = -x-\mu_2, r_2=-x+\mu_1 \]

Substituting the above condition into Equation

\[ \frac{\partial V}{\partial x} = \mu_1(\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \cdot \frac{(x+\mu_2)}{r_1} +\mu_2(\frac{-1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \cdot \frac{(x-\mu_1)}{r_2} = 0 \\ = \mu_1(\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \cdot \frac{(-r_1)}{r_1} +\mu_2(\frac{1}{r_2^2}+r_2) \cdot \frac{r_2}{r_2} = 0 ~~~~~(\because r_2 = 1+ r_1) \\ = \mu_1(\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) \cdot (-1) +\mu_2[\frac{1}{(1+ r_1)^2}+(1+ r_1)] = 0 \\ \implies \mu_1(\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) = \mu_2[\frac{1}{(1+ r_1)^2}+(1+ r_1)] \]

Here, let \(r_1 = 1+ \beta\), \(r_2 = 1+r_1 = 2+\beta\)

\[ \mu_1(\frac{-1}{r_1^2}+r_1) = \mu_2[\frac{1}{(1+ r_1)^2}+(1+ r_1)] \\ \implies \mu_1(\frac{-1}{(1+\beta)^2}+ (1+\beta)) = \mu_2[\frac{1}{(1+ (1+\beta))^2}+(1+ (1+\beta))] \\ \implies \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1} = [\frac{-1}{(1+\beta)^2}+ (1+\beta)] \cdot [\frac{1}{(2+\beta)^2}+(2+\beta))]^{-1} \]

Using binomial series, calculate the part of Equation

\[ \frac{1}{(1+\beta)^2} = (1+\beta)^{-2} \\ = (1+x)^n \\ = 1+nx + \frac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2 + \mathcal{O}(x^3) \\ ~~~(\because n=-2, ~ x=\beta) \\ = 1 - 2\beta + \frac{(-2)(-3)}{2}\beta^2 \\ = 1 - 2\beta + 3\beta^3 \]

Using binomial series, calculate the part of Equation

\[ \frac{1}{(2+\beta)^2} = \frac{1}{(4+4\beta+4\beta^2)} \\ = \frac{1}{4(1+\beta+\frac{1}{4}\beta^2)} \\ = \frac{1}{4}( 1+nx + \frac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2) \\ (\because n=-1~, ~ x=\beta+ \frac{1}{4}\beta^2, \\ x^2 =(\beta+ \frac{1}{4}\beta^2)^2 = \beta^2 + \frac{1}{2}\beta^3 +\frac{1}{16}\beta^4 ~~) \\ = \frac{1}{4} (1-\beta-\frac{1}{4}\beta^2 + \beta^2 +\frac{1}{2}\beta^3 + \frac{1}{16}\beta^4 ) \\ = \frac{1}{4} - \frac{1}{4}\beta + \frac{3}{16}\beta^2 +\frac{1}{8}\beta^3 +\frac{1}{64}\beta^4 \\ = \frac{1}{4} - \frac{1}{4}\beta + \frac{3}{16}\beta^2 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^3) \]

Substituting the result of Equation and into Equation

\[ \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1} = [\frac{-1}{(1+\beta)^2}+ (1+\beta)] \cdot [\frac{1}{(2+\beta)^2}+(2+\beta))]^{-1} \\ = ( -1+ 2\beta - 3\beta^3 +1+ \beta) \cdot (\frac{1}{4} - \frac{1}{4}\beta + \frac{3}{16}\beta^2 -2-\beta)^{-1} \\ = (3\beta -3\beta^2)(\frac{-7}{4}-\frac{5}{4}\beta+\frac{3}{16}\beta^2 )^{-1} \]

The part of Equation

\[ (\frac{-7}{4}-\frac{5}{4}\beta+\frac{3}{16}\beta^2 )^{-1} = \frac{1}{(\frac{-7}{4}-\frac{5}{4}\beta+\frac{3}{16}\beta^2 )} \\ = \frac{1}{\frac{-7}{4}(1+\frac{5}{7}\beta-\frac{3}{28}\beta^2)} \\ = \frac{-4}{7}\frac{1}{(1+\frac{5}{7}\beta-\frac{3}{28}\beta^2)} \\ = \frac{-4}{7}( 1+nx + \frac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2) \\ (\because n= -1~, ~ x=\frac{5}{7}\beta-\frac{3}{28}\beta^2, \\ ~~~ x^2 =(\frac{5}{7}\beta-\frac{3}{28}\beta^2)^2 = \frac{35}{49}\beta^2 - \frac{30}{196}\beta^3 +\frac{9}{784}\beta^4 ~~) \\ = \frac{-4}{7}[1-\frac{5}{7}\beta+\frac{3}{28}\beta^2 + \frac{1}{2}(-1)(-2)(\frac{35}{49}\beta^2 - \frac{30}{196}\beta^3 +\frac{9}{784}\beta^4) ] \\ = \frac{-4}{7}[1-\frac{5}{7}\beta+\frac{3}{28}\beta^2 + \frac{35}{49}\beta^2 - \frac{30}{196}\beta^3 +\frac{9}{784}\beta^4 ] \\ = \frac{-4}{7}[1-\frac{5}{7}\beta+ \frac{3}{28}\beta^2 + \frac{35}{49}\beta^2 - \frac{30}{196}\beta^3 + \frac{9}{784}\beta^4 ] \\ = \frac{-4}{7}[1-\frac{5}{7}\beta+ \frac{161}{1372}\beta^2 - \frac{30}{196}\beta^3 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5) ] \]

Substituting the result of Equation into Equation

\[ \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1} = (3\beta -3\beta^2)(\frac{-7}{4}-\frac{5}{4}\beta+\frac{3}{16}\beta^2 )^{-1} \\ = 3(\beta -\beta^2) \cdot \frac{-4}{7}[1-\frac{5}{7}\beta+ \frac{161}{1372}\beta^2 - \frac{30}{196}\beta^3 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5) \\ = \frac{-12}{7}[\beta - \frac{5}{7}\beta^2 + \frac{161}{1372}\beta^3 - \beta + \frac{5}{7}\beta^3- \frac{161}{1372}\beta^4 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5)] \\ = \frac{-12}{7}[\beta - \frac{12}{7}\beta^2 + \frac{163}{196}\beta^3 -\frac{161}{1372}\beta^4 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5) ] \\ = \frac{-12}{7}\beta + \frac{144}{49}\beta^2 - \frac{1956}{1372}\beta^3 + \frac{1932}{9604}\beta^4 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5) \\ \implies \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1} =\frac{-12}{7}\beta + \frac{144}{49}\beta^2-\frac{1956}{1372}\beta^3 + \frac{1932}{9604}\beta^4 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5) \]

Let \(\alpha = \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1}\), and \(k= \frac{12}{7}\beta\) , the higher terms of Equation is neglected, because the value id small.

\[ \alpha = \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1} =\frac{-12}{7}\beta + \frac{144}{49}\beta^2 -\frac{1956}{1372}\beta^3 + \frac{1932}{9604}\beta^4 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5) \\ = \frac{-12}{7}\beta + \frac{144}{49}\beta^2 +\mathcal{O}(\beta^3) \\ = -k + k^2 +\mathcal{O}(k^3) \]

Using Lagrangianâ€™s inversion method to invert the series expansions in Equation

\[ k = -\alpha + k^2 +\mathcal{O}(k^3) \\ = -\alpha + (1)\cdot \phi(k) ~~~~(\because e = 1 ) \]

\[ \implies \phi(k) = k^2 + \mathcal{O}(k^3) \]

And hence

\[ \implies \phi(\alpha) = \alpha^2 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^3) \]

\[ \frac{12}{7}\beta = k = -\alpha + \alpha^2 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^3) \\ \implies \beta = \frac{-7}{12}\alpha + \frac{7}{12}\alpha^2 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^3) \\ = \frac{-7}{12} (\frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1}) + \frac{7}{12}((\frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1})^2) + \mathcal{O}((\frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1})^3) \]

From previous condition,

\[ r_1 = 1 + \beta \\ = x + \mu_2 \\ \implies x = -r_1 - \mu_2 \\ = -(1+\beta) - \mu_2 \\ = -1 +(\frac{-7}{12}\alpha + \frac{7}{12}\alpha^2) + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^3) - \mu_2 \\ = -1 - \mu_2 + \frac{-7}{12} (\frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1}) - \frac{7}{12}((\frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1})^2) + \mathcal{O}((\frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1})^3) \]

This is location of \(L_3\) point on the negative \(x\)-axis.

References

  1. Murray C D, Dermott S F.\(\textit{ Solar System Dynamics}.\) Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1999: 316
  2. Fowles and Cassiday.\(\textit{Analytical Mechanics}.\) Cengage Learning, 2004
  3. The circular restricted three-body problem. Carlo Nipoti, Dipartimento di Fisica e Astronomia, Universit`a di Bologna
  4. Lecture L18 - Exploring the Neighborhood: the Restricted Three-Body Problem
  5. The restricted three-body problem (1): Equation of motion, The Jacobi Integral, and The Tisserand Relation
  6. The restricted three-body problem (2): Lagrangian points and the stability analysis

entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:
Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub.

Quick Start

Create a new post

More info: Writing

Run server

Generate static files

Deploy to remote sites

entry.title: Tisserand relation
entry.content:
Tisserand Relation T_J

Consider a comet is not close with initial semi-major \(a\), eccentricity \(e\), inclination \(i\). After encountering Jupiter, the orbital element of the comet becomes semi-major \(a'\), eccentricity \(e'\), inclination \(i'\)

From the Jacobi integral \(C_J\), it remains constant value throughout the encounter with the masses \(^{[3]}\).

\[ C_J = 2V - v^2 \\ = 2(\frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2}) + 2n(\dot x' y' - x' \dot y') - ( \dot x'^2 + \dot y'^2 + \dot z'^2 ) \label{1} \] For instance in Sun-Jupiter-comet problem, because the mass of Jupiter is smaller than Sun \((M_j \sim 10^{-3}M_\odot)\), we take \(\mu_1\) and \(r_1\) as the unity. refer oto eq. \(\ref{1}\) \[ GM_\odot = \mu_1 = \mu \]

\[ r_1 = r \]

When the comet is not close to Jupiter, so that \(\frac{\mu_2}{r_2}\) term is always small to neglect the \(\mu_2\) term.

\[\frac{\mu_2}{r_2} \ll \frac{\mu_1}{r_1}=\frac{\mu}{r}\]

Where \(\mu_2 = GM_J\), \(r_2\) is the distance between Jupiter and the comet.

Then, we can consider the approximation of two-body problem between Sun and comet. From the orbital energy of Sun-comet two-body problem.

\[ E = \frac{1}{2}(\ddot x^2 +\ddot y^2 +\ddot z^2 ) - \frac{G(M_\odot+ m_{comet})}{r_1} = -\frac{G(M_\odot+ m_{comet})}{2a} \]

Here, \(G(M_\odot+ m_{comet}) \approx GM_\odot = \mu_1 = \mu\), so we calculate the velocity

\[ v^2 = (\ddot x^2 +\ddot y^2 +\ddot z^2 ) = G(M_\odot+ m_{comet})(\frac{2}{r_1}-\frac{1}{a}) \\ \implies v^2 = \mu(\frac{2}{r}-\frac{1}{a}) \]

$$

$$

For the angular momentum of the orbit

\[ \vec{h} = \vec{r} \times \vec{\dot r} = n\sqrt{a(1-e^2)GM} \\ = n\sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} = constant \] $$

For the orbital energy,

\[ E = \vec h \cdot \vec n \\ &= h \cdot n \cos{i} \\ &= n\sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \cdot n \cos{i} \] the \(z'\) component of \(\vec h\) is given by

\[ 2n(\dot x' y' - x' \dot y') =Â  h \cdot n \cos{i} \] So, Jocobi integral \(C_J\) becomes

\[ C_J &= 2V - v^2 \\ &= 2(\frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2}) + 2n(\dot x' y' - x' \dot y') - ( \dot x'^2 + \dot y'^2 + \dot z'^2 ) \\ & (\because \frac{\mu_1}{r_1} \gg \frac{\mu_2}{r_2}\approx 0 , \mu_1\approx\mu, r_1 \approx r ) \\ &= \frac{2\mu}{r} + 2n(\dot x' y' - x' \dot y')- v^2 \\ & = \frac{2\mu}{r} + 2h \cdot n \cos{i} - (\frac{2\mu}{r}- \frac{\mu}{a}) \\ &= \frac{\mu}{a} + 2h \cdot n \cos{i} \\ & = \frac{\mu}{a} + 2 \cdot n\sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \cdot n \cos{i} ~~~~ (\because n= 1) \\ &= \frac{\mu}{a} + 2\sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \cdot \cos{i} \]

\[ C_J = \frac{\mu}{a} + 2\sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \cdot \cos{i}Â  \approx constant \]

If the comet is not close to Jupiter, so that \(\frac{1}{r_2}\) is always small to neglect the \(\mu_2\) term in Equation , then we have

\[Â T_J = \frac{1}{2} C_J = \frac{\mu}{2a} + \sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \cdot \cos{i}Â  \approx constantÂ \]

Therefore, the approximate relationship with the orbital element of the comet before and after encountering with Jupiter is given by

\[ T_J = \frac{\mu}{2a} + \sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \cdot \cos{i} = \frac{\mu}{2a'} + \sqrt{a'(1-e'^2)\mu} \cdot \cos{i'} \label{10} \] By measuring the orbital elements of the comet, we can check whether the comet is new observed, or is the passage of a previously observed comet scattered by a close encounter with Jupiter. the result is shown as Equation \(\ref{10}\).

\[ \displaylines{x+y\\y+z} \]

entry.title: Install the Linux system on Windows
entry.content:
ä¸­æ–‡ç‰ˆ

Step 1 å•Ÿç”¨Windows Linux System

éœ€è¦å…ˆå•Ÿç”¨ Windows Linux Subsystem åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚éœ€åœ¨ã€é–‹å•Ÿæˆ–é—œé–‰ Windows åŠŸèƒ½ä¸­è¨­å®šã€ï¼Œå‰›è£å®Œç•¢å¾Œï¼Œéœ€è¦é‡æ–°é–‹æ©Ÿã€‚

Step 2 å®‰è£Ubuntu

æ¥è‘—åˆ°Windows Store è£¡å°±æœ‰ Ubuntu App å¯ä»¥é¸æ“‡å®‰è£

å®‰è£æˆåŠŸå¾Œï¼Œå°±å¯ä»¥åœ¨ Windows é¸å–®æ‰¾åˆ° Ubuntu App

  • å•Ÿå‹•Ubuntuå¾Œå»ç™¼ç¾å‡ºç¾éŒ¯èª¤è¨Šæ¯â€¦..

    é€™è¡¨ç¤ºWindows-Subsystem-Linux (WSL)é‚„æ²’æ‰“é–‹ï¼Œå› æ­¤å¯ä»¥ç”¨æ¥ä¸‹ä¾†çš„æ–¹æ³•è§£æ±ºã€‚

Step 3 é–‹å•ŸPowerShell

è¼¸å…¥ä»¥ä¸‹æŒ‡ä»¤:

Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName Microsoft-Windows-Subsystem-Linux

Step 4 å•Ÿå‹•Ubuntu

å®‰è£æˆåŠŸï¼

åŸæœ¬çš„ C/D/F æ§½éƒ½ mount åœ¨ /mnt ä¸‹

è¼¸å…¥cd /mnt/c/Users/*Name/Desktop

*Name: æ ¹æ“šè‡ªå·±çš„é›»è…¦åç¨±å»ä¿®æ”¹

Step 5 æ›´æ–°å¥—ä»¶

è¼¸å…¥ sudo apt-get update

Done!

English version

Step 1. Turn on Windows Linux Subsystem

  1. PressÂ â€œWindowsâ€Â + â€œRâ€ keys simultaneously to open the Run prompt.
  2. Type in â€œControlÂ Panelâ€
  3. Click on the â€œProgramsÂ andÂ Featuresâ€ option.
  4. Select the â€œTurn Windows Features On or OFFâ€ option in the left pane.
  5. Scroll down and select â€œWindows Subsystem for Linuxâ€œ
  6. 6.ClickÂ on â€œOKâ€ to enable the feature.

Step 2 Install Ubuntu

  1. Open the Microsoft Store from the Start menu, and search for â€œUbuntuâ€ in the store
  2. To install , click it, and then click the â€œGetâ€ or â€œInstallâ€ button to install it like any other Store application.

Step 3 Turning WSL ON Through PowerShell

  1. Search forÂ PowerShell, right-click the top result, and select theÂ Run as administratorÂ option.

  2. Type the following command to enable the Linux subsystem and pressÂ Enter:

    Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName Microsoft-Windows-Subsystem-Linux

    TypeÂ YÂ and pressÂ EnterÂ to confirm and restart your computer.

Step 4 Open Ubuntu

  1. OpenÂ Start, and click it .

It works!

Step 5 Update

This is the first time you are using your system after installing, you should run the update command: sudo apt-get update

Done!
